ap-1-1.name: Dog Food
sources: Okin (2017) Environmental impacts of food consumption by dogs and cats

ap-1-1-2.name: Wet Dog Food
ap-1-1-2.notes: Higher footprint due to moisture content and metal packaging

ap-1-2.name: Cat Food
ap-1-2.notes: Higher protein content than dog food

ap-1-3.name: Bird Food
ap-1-3.notes: Seed-based, lower footprint than meat-based pet food

ap-1-5.name: Small Animal Food
ap-1-5.notes: Rabbits, guinea pigs, hamsters - mostly hay/grain based

ap-2-1.name: Dog Collars
ap-2-1.notes: Leather collars have different footprint profile

ap-2-6.name: Dog Bowls
ap-2-6.notes: Stainless steel vs ceramic vs plastic varies

ap-5-6.name: Aquarium Gravel
ap-5-6.notes: Low processing, mainly extraction and transport

aa-1.name: Clothing
aa-1.notes: Parent category - use subcategories for more accurate estimates

weight.methodology: Broad average across all clothing types

aa-1-8.name: Outerwear
aa-1-8.notes: High variance - down jackets lighter, winter coats heavier

aa-1-8-2.name: Down Jackets
aa-1-8-2.notes: Down has high footprint but excellent warmth-to-weight

aa-1-8-7.name: Leather Jackets
aa-1-8-7.notes: Leather has high footprint; faux leather ~60% lower

weight.methodology: Based on standard adult cotton t-shirts

aa-2-1.name: Belts
aa-2-1.notes: Leather belts - synthetic alternatives have ~40% lower footprint

aa-2-10.name: Watches
aa-2-10.notes: Varies greatly by type - digital vs mechanical

aa-3-4.name: Handbags
aa-3-4.notes: Leather handbags - higher for exotic leathers

aa-3-6.name: Tote Bags
aa-3-6.notes: Canvas totes lower footprint than leather

aa-4.name: Jewelry
aa-4.notes: Very small weights but high value and footprint per gram

aa-4-1.name: Bracelets
aa-4-1.notes: Precious metals have very high per-kg footprint

aa-4-4.name: Rings
aa-4-4.notes: Gold rings - silver and costume jewelry much lower

aa-4-7.name: Costume Jewelry
aa-4-7.notes: Much lower footprint than precious metals

aa-5.name: Shoes
aa-5.notes: Wide variance between sandals and boots

aa-5-2.name: Boots
aa-5-2.notes: Leather boots have higher footprint than synthetic

ae-1.name: Art Supplies
ae-1.notes: Highly variable category - weights depend on medium and quantity

ae-1-1-1.name: Acrylic Paints
ae-1-1-1.notes: Typical tube 60ml = ~80g, set of paints varies

ae-2-1-7.name: Fabric
ae-2-1-7.notes: Varies significantly by fabric type and weight

ae-2-5-3.name: Pottery Clay
ae-2-5-3.notes: Low embodied carbon but firing adds significant energy use

ae-2-6-1.name: Candle Wax
ae-2-6-1.notes: Soy wax ~2.0 kg CO2e/kg, paraffin ~3.5 kg CO2e/kg

ae-2-6-3.name: Soap Base
sources: European Oleochemicals & Allied Products Group LCA data

ae-3.name: Musical Instruments
ae-3.notes: Extremely variable - from harmonicas to pianos

ae-8-3.name: Photo Albums
sources: Print and paper products LCA data

bt-1-1-2.name: Lightweight Strollers
bt-1-1-2.notes: Lighter materials often have higher per-kg footprint

bt-4-1.name: Baby Bottles
bt-4-1.notes: Glass bottles heavier but lower footprint per use

bt-5.name: Diapering
bt-5.notes: Per diaper vs per pack varies greatly

bt-5-1.name: Disposable Diapers
bt-5-1.notes: Per-use footprint; cloth diapers have different profile

bt-5-2.name: Cloth Diapers
bt-5-2.notes: Higher upfront footprint but reusable; washing impacts vary

bt-7-1.name: Baby Monitors
bt-7-1.notes: Video monitors have higher footprint than audio-only

lca.methodology: Based on Dell and HP sustainability reports
Smartphone average based on manufacturer reports

el-3.name: Audio
el-3.notes: Extremely variable - earbuds to home theater systems

el-3-2.name: Speakers
el-3-2.notes: Portable bluetooth speakers ~300g, home speakers much heavier

el-4.name: TVs & Monitors
el-4.notes: Weight and impact scales significantly with screen size

fr-1.name: Chairs
fr-1.notes: Highly variable - dining chairs to recliners

fr-6.name: Outdoor Furniture
fr-6.notes: Often metal or plastic for weather resistance

fr-7.name: Kids Furniture
fr-7.notes: Scaled down versions - lighter than adult furniture

hb-1.name: Skin Care
hb-1.notes: Product weight varies; packaging adds significantly

hb-1-2.name: Moisturizers
hb-1-2.notes: Glass jars have higher packaging footprint than tubes

hb-1-5.name: Face Masks
hb-1-5.notes: Sheet masks have high packaging-to-product ratio

hb-1-7.name: Eye Creams
hb-1-7.notes: Small size means high packaging ratio

hb-2-3.name: Hair Styling Products
hb-2-3.notes: Aerosols have higher footprint than gels/creams

hb-3.name: Makeup
hb-3.notes: Very small products with significant packaging

hb-4-3.name: Body Spray
hb-4-3.notes: Aerosol cans have additional propellant footprint

hb-5-8.name: Bar Soap
hb-5-8.notes: Lower packaging footprint than liquid soap

hg-6.name: Kitchen & Dining
hg-6.notes: Highly variable - from utensils to appliances

hg-6-3.name: Drinkware
hg-6-3.notes: Glass and ceramic have different footprints

hg-6-7.name: Kitchen Appliances
hg-6-7.notes: Very high variance - toasters to refrigerators

hg-2-3.name: Duvets & Comforters
hg-2-3.notes: Down-filled have higher footprint than synthetic

hg-3-7.name: Rugs
hg-3-7.notes: Weight varies significantly with size and material

hg-7-1.name: Light Bulbs
hg-7-1.notes: LED bulbs - incandescent have much higher use-phase impact

hg-4.name: Lawn & Garden
hg-4.notes: Extremely variable - seeds to lawn mowers

hg-5.name: Outdoor Furniture
hg-5.notes: See Furniture vertical for more detail

hg-9-2.name: Baskets
hg-9-2.notes: Natural materials vs plastic varies significantly

hg-11-7.name: Thermostats
hg-11-7.notes: Smart thermostats save significant energy use

lb-1.name: Luggage
lb-1.notes: LCA data needed - varies significantly by material

lb-5-5.name: Reusable Shopping Bags
sources: UK Environment Agency bag LCA study
lb-5-5.notes: Must be reused 10+ times to offset production

sg-1.name: Exercise & Fitness
sg-1.notes: Ranges from resistance bands to treadmills

sg-1-2-1.name: Dumbbells

weight.methodology: Per single dumbbell - varies by weight class

sg-1-2-1.notes: Weight IS the product - LCA per kg is key metric

sg-1-3-1.name: Yoga Mats
sg-1-3-1.notes: TPE/natural rubber mats have lower footprint

sg-2-1-1.name: Road Bikes
sg-2-1-1.notes: Carbon frames have higher embodied carbon but lower weight

sg-2-1-3.name: Electric Bikes
sg-2-1-3.notes: Battery production is significant portion of footprint

sg-6-2.name: Sleeping Bags
sg-6-2.notes: Down-filled bags have different footprint profile

sg-5-15.name: Baseball Bats
sg-5-15.notes: Aluminum bats heavier (~850g) with higher footprint

weight.methodology: Varies by set size - average medium set

tg-2-4.name: Wooden Building Blocks
tg-2-4.notes: Lower footprint than plastic, potential carbon storage

tg-3-4.name: Chess Sets
tg-3-4.notes: Weight varies by material - wood vs plastic vs stone

tg-4.name: Video Games
tg-4.notes: Physical media vs consoles have huge weight difference

tg-4-5.name: Physical Game Media
tg-4-5.notes: Digital downloads have lower product footprint but server impact

tg-6-4.name: Electric Ride-Ons
tg-6-4.notes: Battery adds significant weight and footprint

tg-7-1.name: STEM Toys
tg-7-1.notes: Includes electronics kits, science sets, robotics
